thank you so much for joining us today
and talking to us about your experience
that GoDaddy could you share a little
bit about your role sure and thanks for
having me I'm the chief technology
officer at GoDaddy which basically means
I'm responsible for the technical
direction for the company and also the
engineering standards and practices that
we use across the company so that
includes moving our services to AWS
implementing machine learning the
quality and other guidelines that we set
across the company Wow very cool role
and could you tell us a little bit about
GoDaddy and kind of the the
transformation journey that GoDaddy is
on yeah so go down he's really focused
on helping small businesses get online
so we're probably best known for selling
domain names but obviously we help them
with a lot of other areas for building a
website hosting their email getting
found through search engines and things
of that nature so we're really focused
on this you know really small business
market essentially a lot of these folks
don't have a lot of extra time to take
on those technical functions we really
try to focus on making it as easy as
possible for them to get online drills
so you and I've had some robust
conversations about diversity and
inclusion could you talk a little bit
about what that means at GoDaddy so it's
a very important aspect for us obviously
we think that having a diverse and
inclusive environment for employees
helps us better address the diverse and
unique needs that our customers have and
so we really want to try to represent
that I think we've been a leader in that
field in terms of providing very visible
information in terms of pay parity and
the diversity numbers we're one of the
first companies to come out with a lot
of that information and we are
continuing to experiment with different
methods to basically help us along that
curve your vision for where you're
trying to get with GoDaddy you you have
you know such a great value prop now
what's next well essentially I think
half of it is just making it even easier
for us
to use the products that we already have
we're obviously the market leader in
domain names we're depending on exactly
which number you want to look at we're
one of the largest hosting companies in
the world we're the largest WordPress
hoster in the world and essentially what
we want to do is make that customer
experience even better you know we
talked a little bit about innovation and
experimentation on behalf of your
customers can you talk some more about
how you organize your teams how you
inspire that innovation yeah so they're
two different aspects of that I think
part of it is basically the spark of
creativity which i think is a little bit
harder to actually inspire I think the
other part of it is having the formula
to actually enable that experimentation
and so we've come up with a formula
where we expect the teams to come up
with a hypothesis to have the data that
they're going to measure that you know a
result of that experiment against to
actually build the experiment and then
to run it and basically it's a
continuous cycle of taking an idea you
know building data backed experiment
against it and then you know capturing
the data to determine was it successful
was it not successful and many times the
unsuccessful experiments are just as
instructive as the ones that the metric
does move in the way you want it to
because ultimately it's a data point
that you found that you know helps you
identify what really does and what
doesn't resonate with customers and so I
think that's the part that we've really
been focused on today is building that
mechanism in place and you know I think
I've expressed this to many of our teams
it's almost like riding a bicycle it is
something that is new and unique to many
teams initially to figure out that there
is a process around it and I think once
the you know you've ridden the bike
around the yard a couple of times I mean
you're ready for the open road and also
can help show other folks how to follow
that process yeah I'd love that and that
of course really resonates with us at
Amazon because we very much believe in
learning from failures I love that idea
so Charles as a leader in ITU of course
work with your other functional leaders
across your business when you're trying
to prioritize work and these experiments
that we've talked about how do you
communicate that to the other business
leaders well one of the things that
we've come up with is what we call
horizon so horizon one being the more
steady-state businesses which we invest
in differently than horizon two which is
kind of a up-and-coming type of business
and then horizon three which is really
the brand-new nascent idea and this is
something that we're constantly you know
editing and trying different forms but
effectively what we want to do is make
sure that we have metrics that we
determine yes this is successful and
it's growing and in the way that we want
and we're going to keep investing at a
specified rate and you know for you know
the more established businesses there's
just a different investment you know
rate and and so I think that that's you
know kind of an important way to lay out
the landscape Charles it seems like
there's a lot of parallels between

does from a customer obsession and
customer focus can you talk a little bit
more about how you define the customer
outcome that you're trying to drive and
how do you then inspire the team to to
work against that yeah that's a great
question and I think we have moved over
time from defining success as they
bought a product to they're actually
using a product and even that is
starting to you know iterate from they
connected a domain to a website to
actually they have published content on
their site they are actively getting
traffic and so we're constantly moving
the metric by which we define that
customer success you know as we learn
and you know basically as we start
accomplishing some of the goals that
we've set out okay they bought it they
connected it now they're publishing
content so just moving that bar
constantly forward and this is one of
the areas where we are using machine
learning to basically figure out the
uniqueness of the customer you know some
customers basically just want to get
email accounts and start sending email
some of them want to build sites
ecommerce sites upload content sell
online some of
syndicated you know through Amazon and
ultimately we're trying to get much
better at identifying what each unique

along that step Charles thank you so
much for joining us today and sharing
such great insights thank you
